4. You pay attention to your moral compass to determine right from wrong and are less interested in the cold, hard facts.
5. You consider the effect of your actions on other people
6. you are concerned with values and what is best for the people involved.
How do you prefer to plan the work ?: 1. You are spontaneous with the given tasks.
2. You are a Multitasker.
3. You don't need a plan or clarity to start work.
4. You want to be independent.
5. You dislike structure and are carefree.
6. You tend to be flexible and adaptable.
7. You always keep your options open.

ISFP.Communication Style: You are gentle, accepting communicators who tend to follow the flow of conversation and look for opportunities to contribute with factual information or practical help. You are easygoing and supportive; you don’t want to be in control or attract attention and are often attentive listeners. Considerate and accepting, you often look for common ground with others. You shy away from conflict or criticism, preferring harmonious, spontaneous interactions that allow you to be helpful and kind.
ISFP.Values and Motivations:
You tend to be tolerant and nonjudgmental, but are deeply loyal to the people and causes that matter to them. You endeavour to accept and support other people but are ultimately guided by their own core values. You will typically look for ways to be accommodating and may have difficulty dealing with others who are not willing to do the same.
You are typically modest and may underestimate yourself. You usually do not like to be in the spotlight, preferring instead to take a supporting role, and will avoid planning and organizing whenever possible. Sensitive and responsive, you step in to do what needs to be done and are satisfied by their personal sense of being helpful to others.
ISFP.Work Place Habits:
You want to feel personally engaged with your work, and seek careers which allow you to express yourself or participate in a cause you believe in. you typically enjoy hands-on activities, and often gain satisfaction when you can create a tangible result from your efforts. An ideal job for you allows you to clearly observe the fruits of your labour, in a context that feels significant and consistent with your values.
You like a courteous, cooperative work environment where you can work quietly, with support when you need it. Because you are so tuned to your physical surroundings, it's often important to you that your work environment is aesthetically pleasing.
You generally prefer to keep a low profile and do not usually like to be in positions that require you to speak publicly or lead large groups. Although you often prefer to work independently, when you do work with others, you want your colleagues to be flexible, supportive, and loyal to the team.
ISFP.How Others Perceive You:
You can be difficult to recognize because of your tendency to express yourself through action rather than words. You may initially appear distant or aloof, but if you watch closely, one can observe you caring in the thoughtful things you do for others. You are carefully observant of the practical needs of other people and often step in with quiet, unassuming assistance at just the moment it is needed. You prefer to take a supportive role and are rarely assertive or demanding of attention. You are typically tolerant and accepting of others.
You typically have finely tuned artistic sensibilities. You are sensitive to colour texture, and tone, and often have an innate sense of what will be aesthetically pleasing. You are often natural when it comes to arranging something artistically and enjoy the process of taking in the sensations around you. You focus mostly on the experiences of the present moment, and are rarely ambitious, preferring instead to enjoy the simple pleasures of life: friends, family, and sensory delights such as food, music, and art.

Growth Potential.Choose honesty over harmony: You do what you can to preserve harmony and promote peace. But in order to avoid having your needs overlooked, you need to express yourself openly and honestly, even if what you have to say may be difficult for others to hear. This can cause strife in the short run, but in the long run, it will help clear up misunderstandings and erase hurt feelings.
Growth Potential.Develop a wider concept of what it means: You tend to underestimate your own skills and intelligence. As a result, you frequently choose not to express yourself or volunteer your services unless you are absolutely certain you will receive a positive reception. But when you surrender to these sorts of insecurities, you are actually passing up opportunities for adventure, which you normally crave. There’s a satisfaction to be gained from breaking free of these chains. The results may be unpredictable, but the uncertainty is what provides the challenge.
Growth Potential.As Michael Jackson used to say, start wi: You have wonderful personal qualities. Your unselfishness and charitable attitude rank near the top of the list of your most attractive attributes. But you are so open-minded, respectful, considerate and polite that you tend to defer to others in virtually every circumstance. Too often, you treat others better than you treat yourself, acting as if your needs are somehow trivial or less important. So every now and then, you should make sure to include your own names on the list of the deserving—preferably somewhere near the top. Charity shouldn’t end at home, but there is no reason why it can’t begin there.
Growth Potential.Network with dreamers, visionaries and f: You are a bit sceptical of those whose imaginations seem bigger than your accomplishments. In some cases, this is justified, but in general, you could benefit by seeking social contact with people who possess the long-term vision you sometimes lack. Reading autobiographies or downloading video interviews with such folks will also help you gain more insight into the thinking patterns and philosophies of successful entrepreneurs and inventors.
Growth Potential.Actually make some plans for the future: It is possible for you to look ahead without abandoning your spontaneity and freedom. “What would I like to be doing five years from now?” “What does the phrase ‘personal growth’ mean to me?” “What would I like my life to look like when I turn 50?” These are the types of general, open-ended questions that can help you focus your creative energies without restricting your ability to make unique, spur-of-the-moment choices.

Strengths.Perseverance: You’s main and most admirable strength is perseverance; people of this type simply do not give up. This trait is advantageous to you and can be that which sets you apart in your careers. Your peers and competitors may possess greater skills, but few will match you in dogged commitment.
Because of you’s Judging component, people of this type have a very clear command of time and priorities. You are quite skilled in planning, organizing, mapping out schedules and following agendas. You excel in time management, are punctual (and demand the same of others) and consistently meet your deadlines.
Strengths.Detail orientation: You notice holes, gaps, errors that broader thinkers don’t. You like facts, details and numbers without the emotional or interpretive fluff. And you don’t take facts or information for granted, nor do you rely on it simply because someone else said so. You will check things out for yourself, meticulously.
Strengths.Loyalty: You also have a natural instinct to protect and defend. Loyal, reliable and committed, these are people that can be depended on to guard everything from your families to our nation and these are responsibilities you proudly assume. To the institutions, organizations and people to which you are committed, you are unwavering in your service.

Weaknesses.Stubbornness: While you will be admired for your unwavering commitment to your duty and your sense of what is right and proper, the downside of this is that you can be stubborn, inflexible and dogmatic. You often believe there is one right way (yours) and things must be done that way. Everything else is, by default, wrong.
Weaknesses.Tactlessness: You are a fierce commitment to truth can also get you in trouble in interpersonal dealings. You tend to speak without much consideration for the feelings of others, thinking it is always more important to be truthful than to make people feel good. You may even experience internal conflict around trying to be tactful or diplomatic, sensing that you are not being completely honest, direct or straightforward.
Weaknesses.Guilt: You take your work, your commitments and really all aspects of your lives quite seriously and you work hard to plan well and to make wise decisions. When things don’t go as planned, however, you may blame and beat yourself up about it, second guess your decisions and suffer guilt. You will have a hard time simply accepting that sometimes life doesn’t go as planned, and will feel a sense of personal failure and defeat. This can be a source of stress and on-going rumination.
Weaknesses.Resistance to change: You, in your drive to uphold tradition and do things by the book, can be resistant to change and innovation. Suspicious of new advances and ways of doing things, not only do you experience strain when called upon to embrace change, but you also often stifle creativity or fail to appreciate the benefit of approaching old problems in new ways. This can limit your potential and make you seem especially difficult and stodgy to your coworkers and subordinates.

Personality Description.Name: The Analyst
Personality Description.Two Line Description: You're someone who follows steps and procedures to get work done efficiently, at the same time you're reliable and prefer working alone.
Personality Description.Description:
You are responsible organizers, driven to create and enforce order within systems and institutions. You are neat and orderly, inside and out, and tend to have a procedure for everything you do. Reliable and dutiful, you want to uphold tradition and follow regulations.
You are steady, productive contributors. Although you are Introverted, you are rarely isolated; typically you know just where you belong in life, and want to understand how you can participate in established organizations and systems. You concern yourself with maintaining the social order and making sure that standards are met.
Where do you prefer to focus your energy: 1. You gain energy from reflection and lose energy in social gatherings.
2. You are passionate and not usually aggressive.
3.You are a good listener.
4. You are quiet, reserved and self-sufficient.
5. Gain energy from focusing your mind.
6. You are highly Intellectual.
7. You are a deep thinker.
8. You prefer to work alone and not in groups.
How do you grasp and process the informa: 1. You are observant.
2. Your decisions depend on facts and figures.
3. You are rational and realistic.
4. You focus on the present and have a reasonable approach.
5. You use experience and common sense to solve problems.
6. You apply all your senses.
How do you make the decisions?: 1. You enjoy technical and scientific fields where logic is important.
2. You look for logical explanations or solutions to everything.
3. You make decisions rationally.
4. You are task-oriented and focused.
5. You are ruled by your head instead of your heart.
6. You are a critical thinker and oriented toward problem-solving.
How do you prefer to plan the work ?: 1. You prefer being organised and live a planned or orderly way of life.
2. You like to be involved in tasks where there is a standard procedure and do not like ambiguity
3. You like to take charge of things and take responsibilities and leading roles.
4. You are self-disciplined and decisive.
5. You don't procrastinate and complete your work on time.

ISTJ.Communication Style: You communicate in a direct and straightforward way. You are specific and oriented to details, and often communicate primarily to move a task along. You typically have a great memory for detail and has a vast storehouse of practical, factual information. Most you don’t talk for the sake of talking but will share your knowledge when you see a practical need for it. You are often no-nonsense and action-oriented in your communication; you tell what you know and what needs to be done.
ISTJ.Values and Motivations:
You like to know what the rules of the game are, valuing predictability more than imagination. You rely on their past experience to guide you and are most comfortable in familiar surroundings. You trust the proven method and appreciate the value of dedicated practice to build confidence in their skills.
You are hardworking and will persist until a task is done. You are logical and methodical, and often enjoy tasks that require you to use step-by-step reasoning to solve a problem. you are meticulous in their attention to details, and examine things closely to be sure they are correct. With their straightforward logic and orientation to detail, you work systematically to bring order to their own small parts of the world.
ISTJ.Work Place Habits:
At work, you are dependable and meticulous. You take deadlines and specifications very seriously and work independently and systematically to complete the tasks you are given. you value a stable work environment with clear expectations and few surprises. you are at your best when you can create detailed plans of action and follow you with little deviation.
Although you may like to do quite a bit of your work independently, you often appreciate the value of participating on a team as well, especially if your colleagues are reasonable and businesslike and there is a clear hierarchy so that you know who is in charge.
An ideal job for you allows you to solve logical problems in an orderly way. An ideal work environment for you is quiet, organized, and structured, with rules and regulations that are well established and clearly adhered to by all.
ISTJ.How Others Perceive You:
You can be difficult to recognize because of your tendency to express yourself through action rather than words. You may initially appear distant or aloof, but if you watch closely, one can observe you caring in the thoughtful things you do for others. You are carefully observant of the practical needs of other people and often step in with quiet, unassuming assistance at just the moment it is needed. You prefer to take a supportive role and are rarely assertive or demanding of attention. You are typically tolerant and accepting of others.
You typically have finely tuned artistic sensibilities. You are sensitive to colour texture, and tone, and often have an innate sense of what will be aesthetically pleasing. You are often natural when it comes to arranging something artistically and enjoy the process of taking in the sensations around you. You focus mostly on the experiences of the present moment, and are rarely ambitious, preferring instead to enjoy the simple pleasures of life: friends, family, and sensory delights such as food, music, and art.

Growth Potential.Question the procedure: Just because it’s “the way it has always been done” doesn’t mean it is the best or the only way. You find comfort in coasting along following the manner in which things have always been done. However, this can mean missed opportunities for growth and development, both personally and professionally. You will benefit from a willingness to break out of the rut of tradition. It certainly isn’t necessary to reinvent the wheel or fix what isn’t broken, but being willing to at least examine and the question is essential.
Growth Potential.Question the rules: Your refusal to break the rules, while admirable in some respects, can be unwise. Not all rules are just or efficient, and guidelines aren’t all carved in stone. While respect for authority and laws is generally a good thing, it is the duty of society to actively consider and question and, in doing so, serve as a check on authorities and your exercise of power.
Growth Potential.Be spontaneous: You have a strong internal sense of time management. While this is one of the mechanisms that enable you to work hard and meet deadlines, it can also be imprisoning. Then you should experiment with not setting a schedule for the day and letting life happen naturally, or try surprising his or her spouse with an unplanned date.
Growth Potential.Get in touch with your feelings: You, in order to develop and become better-rounded individuals, may need to exert some effort in the emotions department. This will benefit you both in your personal and professional lives. Working to understand and express your own feelings will help to deepen and enliven your friendships and other primary relationships.
Growth Potential.Make time for leisure and personal devel: You often become so laden with the duties of work, family and community that you devote little time to yourself. You, at the very least, need time to consider your lives and to think out the issues you face. You may tend to sideline hobbies because of more pressing responsibilities, but investing time in creative or social endeavours can help you to better fulfil the commitments you see before you and to relieve some of the pressure you experience.

Strengths.Practical and creative: The strength of you has frequently been seen in your technical and mechanical skills, from the tuning of a bicycle to the firing of a gun to the repair of a Formula One race car. You are masterful in your use of tools and your ability to fix, repair and make tools and machines work for you. You are also particularly handy around the house and can fix most anything, putting ideas into motion with your hands.
Strengths.Problem-solving: You excel in problem-solving because you are able to absorb large quantities of sensory information and categorize it effectively and efficiently so it is ready to be called upon when needed, even in the heat of a stressful moment. Confident in your knowledge and your abilities, you are the doers in any emergency, ready to dive in and take action. You don’t sit on the sidelines paralyzed by the stress, you move into it.
Strengths.Common sense and world-savvy: The one thing you will never be called is gullible, as this type possesses a keen ability to accurately size up the character and motives of others with striking reliability. People are unlikely to pull one over on you, but if you do, you will be quite distraught over it, not understanding how you might have been duped.
Strengths.Flexible: You do particularly well in physical endeavours of various types because you are able to insightfully size up your competition and position yourself properly in order to secure the victory. Flexible and adaptable, you improvise quickly in order to respond to the situation, trusting that your bodies and the instincts will guide you.

Weaknesses.Insensitive: You tend toward blunt and unsweetened communication and in many ways, this can be a strength because it means you are honest, direct and logical. But in excess, it becomes quite harsh and critical, especially if people don’t meet you’s standards of what constitutes logic, reason or practicality. Rather than accepting that people simply think differently, then you can become irritated when made to deal with a way of thinking that is not natural for you.
Weaknesses.Risk-seeking behaviour: You’s restlessness, tendency to become bored and constant pursuit of the thrill can lead you to pursue risky and even reckless behaviours, not fully weighing the costs of your actions. While hedonism is a natural tendency of you, some are particularly unwise in your quest for pleasure, thrills, the adrenaline rush and instant gratification, claiming “you only live once.”
Weaknesses.Impatient: You don’t deal well with the inability to move forward, make a decision or act at the moment. Waiting and deliberating is the much greater challenge. Your inability to be patient and your aversion to being bored can fuel you impulsiveness and hedonism in unhealthy ways as you seek your adrenaline fix.
Weaknesses.Private and reserved: You have a strong need for personal space and solitude. In and of itself, this preference need not be classified as a weakness, though problems arise when this need dominates and causes you to push others away or avoid intimacy. You can be inordinately protective of you space, your solitude, your schedule and your way of doing things and, like a mama bear, can become quite defensive toward those who seek to move into this space without permission.

Personality Description.Name: The Specialist
Personality Description.Two Line Description: You're detail - oriented and self - motivated in a way to finding creative solutions to problems you notice around you.
Personality Description.Description:
You are observant artisans with an understanding of mechanics and an interest in troubleshooting. You approach their environments with a flexible logic, looking for practical solutions to the problems at hand. You are independent and adaptable and typically interact with the world around you in a self-directed, spontaneous manner.
You are attentive to details and responsive to the demands of the world around you. Because of their astute sense of their environment, you are good at moving quickly and responding to emergencies. You are reserved, but not withdrawn: you enjoy taking action and approach the world with a keen appreciation for the physical and sensory experiences it has to offer.
Where do you prefer to focus your energy: 1. You gain energy from reflection and lose energy in social gatherings.
2. You are passionate and not usually aggressive.
3.You are a good listener.
4. You are quiet, reserved and self-sufficient.
5. Gain energy from focusing your mind.
6. You are highly Intellectual.
7. You are a deep thinker.
8. You prefer to work alone and not in groups.
How do you grasp and process the informa: 1. You are observant.
2. Your decisions depend on facts and figures.
3. You are rational and realistic.
4. You focus on the present and have a reasonable approach.
5. You use experience and common sense to solve problems.
6. You apply all your senses.
How do you make the decisions?: 1. You enjoy technical and scientific fields where logic is important.
2. You look for logical explanations or solutions to everything.
3. You make decisions rationally.
4. You are task-oriented and focused.
5. You are ruled by your head instead of your heart.
6. You are a critical thinker and oriented toward problem-solving.
How do you prefer to plan the work ?: 1. You are spontaneous with the given tasks.
2. You are a Multitasker.
3. You don't need a plan or clarity to start work.
4. You want to be independent.
5. You dislike structure and are carefree.
6. You tend to be flexible and adaptable.
7. You always keep your options open.

ISTP.Communication Style: You are often a reserved communicator, preferring action to the conversation. You like to do what needs to be done and may grow impatient with a discussion that does not turn quickly to action. You are often observant, picking up on details of the current situation, and evaluate information in a detached and logical way. Typically flexible and tolerant, you are ready to adapt to the situation at hand but can be bluntly critical if you see inefficiency or incompetence.
ISTP.Values and Motivations:
You are curious about the mechanics of the world around you and typically have a unique ability to manipulate the tools in their environments. You tend to study how things work and often achieve mastery in the use and operation of machines, instruments, and equipment. You seek understanding, but in a practical sense: you like to be able to put their technical knowledge to immediate use and are quickly bored by theory.
You tend to be detached and prefer the logic of mechanical things to the complexity of human emotions. Independent and reserved, you treasure their personal space and want to be free to be spontaneous and follow their own lead. You are selective about their relationships and appreciate others who allow you plenty of freedom to do their own thing.
ISTP.Work Place Habits:
At work, you are motivated by a desire to achieve and utilize technical expertise. You enjoy mastering and manipulating the tools of your trade, whatever they may be: the traditional hammers and saws, or the more modern tools of business or technology.
You prefer tasks with a tangible result, and typically feel most satisfied when you have built something concrete. You enjoy troubleshooting and often look for occupations that allow you to apply your skills to solve practical problems.
Many you enjoy occupations that involve physical activity, often with an aspect of risk or danger, and dislike being stuck at a desk. You are most often energized by action and want to jump in to get things done rather than spend much time planning or theorizing.
You value efficiency and logic and want flexibility in your work. You prefer a job where you can be practical and action-oriented without being overly burdened by rules, procedure, or bureaucracy.
ISTP.How Others Perceive You:
You are typically reserved and even aloof. Tolerant and nonjudgmental, you calmly take in the details and facts of your surroundings, noticing sensory data and observing how things work. You often tune into what needs to be done, taking care of the immediate needs of the moment in a modest, inconspicuous way. You tend to prefer action to a conversation and are often private about your personal lives. You are unlikely to “open up” to new people in a conventional way, but may connect with others by sharing an activity or working together to solve a practical problem.

Growth Potential.Make a plan: You are known for your tendency to avoid long-range planning, preferring to make decisions at the moment and live in the present. This means You often fail to take the steps that can help you to advance in your careers and other areas of life. While you don’t need to take you plan and etch it in stone, it helps to have a general framework in order to make decisions and take the steps that can better facilitate a successful career path. Work on setting goals, making commitments and long-range planning.
Growth Potential.Balance opportunism: You inherently understand how to position yourself and work skillfully with the resources and advantages you have in order to succeed. You can, as a result, be exploitative and opportunistic. Then you need to be mindful of his or her goals and motives to make sure that “taking advantage” doesn’t involve taking advantage of someone else.
As Perceiving types, you prefer to let life come and determine the course of your day, rather than taking a proactive role in deciding how your time will be spent and what you will do. Effort spent on developing time management skills can help you gain better control of his or her time in order to actively prioritize and use this time rather than letting the needs of the day or the moment dictate. Better time management strategies can also help people of this type overcome your natural tendency to procrastinate.
Growth Potential.Stop and reflect: You get easily caught up in the moment and engaged in the present situation, and once it’s over you’re on to the next. You spend your lives so externally focused that you often fail to set aside time for introspection, for reflection upon your actions and feelings or to learn from your mistakes. You develop as individuals when you will take a break in the action to spend a little time thinking about your lives, your feelings, where you are going, how you need to grow and what your next steps will be.
Growth Potential.Reframe commitment: In life, love and work, you are generally hesitant to make commitments. You live in the day and focus your energies in the present. As a result, it is difficult for you to conceive of where you will be or what you will want to be doing at some point in the future. To become people who commit successfully, you can begin to think of your commitments as a daily renewal. One need not declare what ten years from now will look like, it’s only necessary to reframe commitment in terms of many small, daily commitments that over time build up to something resembling a long-term achievement.
